newsitem.title: USA: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Expiration or profit-taking?.
newsitem.headline: U.S. OPTIONS FOCUS/Expiration or profit-taking?.

text.p: The expiration Friday of May U.S. stock index options could be one reason for the market's sharp decline, but several options traders said profit-taking was a more likely reason.
In late trading, the bellwether Dow industrial average was down 94 points at 7,239, above its session low of about 7,203 reached in afternoon trading.
Among broader indices, the S&P 100 was off about 10 at 818.27 and the S&P 500 fell roughly nine to 832.71. June S&P 500 futures lost 10 to 834.75.
So was the market down because of the expiration?
"It's possible but I don't see it," said one index options trader. "It's not hitting me over the head."
He noted that the Nasdaq composite index also posted a sharp decline, losing nearly 11 points to about 1,343. It reached a session low at about 1,340.
"You've got Hewlett-Packard down 6-3/8. That took down all the tech stocks and that took down the whole market," said Harrison Roth, a first vice president at Cowen & Co.
Hewlett shares were down 6-3/8 at 52-1/2 on nearly 17 million shares after reporting disappointing fiscal second quarter earnings after the close Thursday.
"I don't think (the selloff) really has anything to do with the expiration," one index option broker said. "I think it's profit-taking.
"What's down 100 (on the Dow) when we've gone up 100 day after day?" the broker said.
He added that uncertainty over next week's Federal Open Market Committee was most likely a driving force behind the profit-taking.
"Nobody knows what (Federal Reserve Chairman) Greenspan is going to do," he said. "They had thought he was going to raise rates, but now they're talking about him not doing it.
"Uncertainty is what kills this market," he added.
Late-session order imbalances from the New York Stock Exchange were all on the sell side.
Through Thursday, options traders were expecting an upside bias to the expiration, but a large number of the OEX calls were exercised Thursday, weakening that argument.
Traders said the sharp selloff in Hewlett off the opening bell effectively wiped out any chance of an early upside move.
May SPX options settled at the SPX opening price Friday and OEX options settle Saturday morning.
Traders said the one sure effect on the market of the expiration was a pickup in volume, at least on the options side.
"They've been in a fast market almost all day," the index options trader said, referring to the OEX trading pit.
In the OEX, the May 820 calls, which until today looked to be expiring in-the-money, were the most active, with turnover of more than 43,100 contracts. They fell 8-15/16 to 1/16.
The OEX May 820 put, which rose 6-1/2 to 7-1/2, traded roughly 43,000 contracts.
((Gregory Crawford, 312 408 8750))
E-mail: derivatives@reuters.com
